newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai copper futures end down on profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai copper futures end down on profit-taking.

text.p: Shanghai copper futures ended down on Monday on profit-taking triggered by last Friday's losses on the London Metal Exchange, traders said.
The most active March 1997 contract ended at 20,620 yuan ($2,484) per tonne, down 40 yuan. It opened down at 20,520 yuan, hitting an intra-day low of 20,500 and a high of 20,650.
December rose 80 to 20,200, January 80 to 20,500, February fell 40 to 20,590, April 30 to 20,620 and May 50 to 20,600.
Combined volume rose to 56,540 tonnes from 51,995.
Copper opened lower but speculative buying pushed the prices up from lows for most of the session.
Traders said LME losses triggered a technical correction in Shanghai, but fresh buying emerged at low levels with market sentiment strong.
"Profit-taking from retail investors dominated today's trade, but copper is likely to rise further in the next few days due to strong market sentiment," one trader said.
"The confidence of long position holders has improved a lot since copper breached the key 20,000-yuan resistance level," he added.
Traders expect copper to consolidate around the 20,500-yuan level due to technical over-buying over the past few days.
"Copper will rise further only if it can hold steady at the current level," a second trader said.
Aluminium ended up. December rose 50 to 13,600 yuan per tonne, January 60 to 13,780 and February 190 to 14,000.
Combined volume rose to 330 tonnes from 200.
